text: “Although many are becoming comfortable spurting out phrases like ‘systemic racism,’ the solutions proposed remain mired in the system that is being critiqued,” @KeeangaYamahtta writes. https://t.co/aZUXExYRx1

name: NewYorker
text: The coronavirus pandemic, as has often been noted, oﬀers an opportunity to reopen with a greater recognition of inequalities. For the school system, there is a risk that the reopening process will only amplify those divisions. https://t.co/msX4hYz9v7

name: NewYorker
text: “With video, I ﬁnd I need to sit still and look, and the drama of faces is much more intense,” a psychoanalyst conducting remote sessions said. “I can see the tears; I can hear the cracks in the voices.” https://t.co/vbPmaZUZEp

name: NewYorker
text: Peter Hessler, a former Peace Corps China volunteer, writes about the political motivations behind the U.S.’s decision to abandon the Peace Corps’s efforts in China.  https://t.co/qRXm3Pyp2A

name: NewYorker
text: Josephine Decker’s new film "Shirley," starring Elisabeth Moss as Shirley Jackson, is an audacious director’s experiment in commercial filmmaking—and it's a successful one. https://t.co/lt1pp0IetW

name: NewYorker
text: William Barr’s response to the nationwide protests is no surprise; for decades, he has been a law-and-order hard-liner who has backed the use of overwhelming police force. https://t.co/uCJbiKiybK

name: NewYorker
text: “If we’re just going to use solar power instead of coal to run the same sad mess of unfair and ugly oppression, is it really worth it?” @billmckibben on the protests taking place across the United States, and why we must face our collective demons. https://t.co/JXO2tH1VzB

name: NewYorker
text: Across the country, political novices, inspired by Bernie Sanders’s Presidential bids and the rise of unapologetically left-wing candidates, have thrown their hats into the electoral ring. https://t.co/wPFREcfSJV

text: Each chapter of Korean history has produced films of startling poise, creativity, and insight. Here are 10 of the best of them, now free to watch on YouTube. https://t.co/21bT5wzoFx

name: NewYorker
text: The elaborate nail stylings made popular by black women have been both derided and appropriated. In a new documentary, they’re honored as art. https://t.co/3sKuBGt7j1
